articles.headline: Banking Crisis Hangs Over Economy, Rekindling Recession Fear
articles.snippet: Borrowing could become tougher, a particular blow to small businesses — and a threat to the recovery’s staying power.
articles.abstract: Borrowing could become tougher, a particular blow to small businesses — and a threat to the recovery’s staying power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economic recovery has repeatedly defied predictions of an impending recession, withstanding supply-chain backlogs, labor shortages, global conflicts and the fastest increase in interest rates in decades.

articles.headline: After Police Killing of Walter Scott, a Department Tries to Rebound
articles.snippet: The North Charleston Police Department has hired more Black officers, cut down on traffic stops and invited Mr. Scott’s brother to speak to recruits.
articles.abstract: The North Charleston Police Department has hired more Black officers, cut down on traffic stops and invited Mr. Scott’s brother to speak to recruits.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Walter Scott, an unarmed Black man, was killed by a police officer in North Charleston, S.C., during a routine traffic stop, the city spun into what is now predictable turmoil: Video of the horrific shooting was everywhere. There were protests, accusations of racist and aggressive policing, demands for reform, and distraught family members speaking out, often flanked by civil rights leaders.

articles.headline: First Republic and Other Banks Seek to Attract Buyers
articles.snippet: Private equity firms and other buyers have been circling failed and struggling banks that are desperately trying to sell off assets or even stakes.
articles.abstract: Private equity firms and other buyers have been circling failed and struggling banks that are desperately trying to sell off assets or even stakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just one day after the biggest U.S. banks gave it a $30 billion infusion, First Republic Bank was in talks to sell a piece of itself to other banks or private equity firms, three people with knowledge of the process said, an indication that the imperiled lender is far from conquering its troubles.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: Arrest Warrant From Criminal Court Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity
articles.snippet: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.
articles.abstract: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The International Criminal Court accused the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, of war crimes and issued a warrant for his arrest on Friday, a highly symbolic step that deepened his isolation and punctured the aura of impunity that has surrounded him since he ordered troops into Ukraine a year ago.

articles.headline: A Question About Your Money: Has Anything Truly Changed This Week?
articles.snippet: Watching the banking industry descend into turmoil is unnerving. But unless your financial goals have changed, embrace inaction.
articles.abstract: Watching the banking industry descend into turmoil is unnerving. But unless your financial goals have changed, embrace inaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks failed. Rich men became publicly agitated, demanding protection. Regulators stepped in to try to stop the panic. Markets wobbled anyway.

articles.headline: 20 Years After U.S. Invasion, Iraq Is a Freer Place, but Not a Hopeful One
articles.snippet: Conversations with dozens of Iraqis offer a portrait of a nation that is rich in oil, hobbled by corruption and unable to guarantee its citizens’ safety.
articles.abstract: Conversations with dozens of Iraqis offer a portrait of a nation that is rich in oil, hobbled by corruption and unable to guarantee its citizens’ safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: A couple of streets away from the new buildings and noisy main road of the desert city of Falluja, there was once a sports stadium. The goal posts are long gone, the stands rotted years ago.

articles.headline: 48 Hours Till Payroll, $200,000 to Go: Diary of a Bank Failure
articles.snippet: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank set major financial disruptions in motion. It also made one founder’s week a scramble.
articles.abstract: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank set major financial disruptions in motion. It also made one founder’s week a scramble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sara Mauskopf’s day-to-day concerns — her customers, her employees, her own three children — don’t typically involve the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. She is the chief executive of Winnie, a start-up that helps families find child care and helps child care providers find customers, serving over 250,000 day cares and millions of families. Ms. Mauskopf, 38, has raised over $15 million for Winnie since its founding in 2016 and employs 29 people. All of her company’s money was in Silicon Valley Bank.

articles.headline: Sandy Hook Families Are Fighting Alex Jones and the Bankruptcy System Itself
articles.snippet: As the families seek more than $1.4 billion awarded by courts for Mr. Jones’s lies, a New York Times review shows he is transferring millions of dollars to family and friends, potentially out of reach of creditors.
articles.abstract: As the families seek more than $1.4 billion awarded by courts for Mr. Jones’s lies, a New York Times review shows he is transferring millions of dollars to family and friends, potentially out of reach of creditors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Infowars conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones, who faces more than $1.4 billion in legal damages for defaming the families of the Sandy Hook shooting victims, has devised a new way to taunt them: wriggling out of paying them the money they are owed.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Williamson and Emily Steel

articles.headline: A Four-Decade Secret: One Man’s Story of Sabotaging Carter’s Re-election
articles.snippet: A prominent Texas politician said he unwittingly took part in a 1980 tour of the Middle East with a clandestine agenda.
articles.abstract: A prominent Texas politician said he unwittingly took part in a 1980 tour of the Middle East with a clandestine agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been more than four decades, but Ben Barnes said he remembers it vividly. His longtime political mentor invited him on a mission to the Middle East. What Mr. Barnes said he did not realize until later was the real purpose of the mission: to sabotage the re-election campaign of the president of the United States.

articles.headline: A Sandwich Shop, a Tent City and an American Crisis
articles.snippet: As homelessness overwhelms downtown Phoenix, a small business wonders how long it can hang on.
articles.abstract: As homelessness overwhelms downtown Phoenix, a small business wonders how long it can hang on.
articles.lead_paragraph: He had been coming into work at the same sandwich shop at the same exact time every weekday morning for the last four decades, but now Joe Faillace, 69, pulled up to Old Station Subs with no idea what to expect. He parked on a street lined with three dozen tents, grabbed his Mace and unlocked the door to his restaurant. The peace sign was still hanging above the entryway. Fake flowers remained undisturbed on every table. He picked up the phone and dialed his wife and business partner, Debbie Faillace, 60.
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Todd Heisler

articles.headline: China as Peacemaker in the Ukraine War? The U.S. and Europe Are Skeptical.
articles.snippet: Chinese officials say Xi Jinping’s upcoming trip to Moscow is a peace mission. But U.S. and European officials say he aims to bolster Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.abstract: Chinese officials say Xi Jinping’s upcoming trip to Moscow is a peace mission. But U.S. and European officials say he aims to bolster Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news of the Putin-Xi summit in Russia.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: UBS Agrees to Buy Rival Credit Suisse
articles.snippet: In a deal brokered by the Swiss government, Switzerland’s largest bank will buy its smaller rival for about $3.2 billion.
articles.abstract: In a deal brokered by the Swiss government, Switzerland’s largest bank will buy its smaller rival for about $3.2 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Switzerland’s largest bank, UBS, agreed on Sunday to buy its beleaguered and longtime rival Credit Suisse for about $3.2 billion, the most drastic bid yet to arrest the financial panic that has swept the globe over the past week.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, Maureen Farrell and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Before Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the Fed Spotted Big Problems
articles.snippet: The bank was using an incorrect model as it assessed its own risks amid rising interest rates, and spent much of 2022 under a supervisory review.
articles.abstract: The bank was using an incorrect model as it assessed its own risks amid rising interest rates, and spent much of 2022 under a supervisory review.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Silicon Valley Bank’s risky practices were on the Federal Reserve’s radar for more than a year — an awareness that proved insufficient to stop the bank’s demise.

articles.headline: Lab Leak or Not? How Politics Shaped the Battle Over Covid’s Origin
articles.snippet: A lab leak was once dismissed by many as a conspiracy theory. But the idea is gaining traction, even as evidence builds that the virus emerged from a market.
articles.abstract: A lab leak was once dismissed by many as a conspiracy theory. But the idea is gaining traction, even as evidence builds that the virus emerged from a market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 2021, with studies of the coronavirus pandemic’s origins going nowhere and the issue embroiled in bitter partisan politics, David Relman, a microbiologist at Stanford, quietly made a request of his congresswoman.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: Iraq, 20 Years Later: A Changed Washington and a Terrible Toll on America
articles.snippet: The White House, Congress, the military and the intelligence agencies see the war as a lesson in failed policymaking, one deeply absorbed if not thoroughly learned.
articles.abstract: The White House, Congress, the military and the intelligence agencies see the war as a lesson in failed policymaking, one deeply absorbed if not thoroughly learned.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month before President George W. Bush first sent American troops into Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was warned that the war might end up costing the United States billions of dollars.

articles.headline: The Chaotic, Dispiriting Work of Liquidating Harmon Stores
articles.snippet: Employees of the beauty and health chain said Bed Bath & Beyond’s decision to shut it down had caught them by surprise. Communication never got better.
articles.abstract: Employees of the beauty and health chain said Bed Bath & Beyond’s decision to shut it down had caught them by surprise. Communication never got better.
articles.lead_paragraph: It had been a busy but successful holiday season at the Harmon Face Values store in Morris Plains, N.J.

articles.headline: Fed Meets as Bank Chaos Collides With Inflation
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve will decide whether and by how much to raise interest rates this week at a moment when its path ahead is newly fraught.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve will decide whether and by how much to raise interest rates this week at a moment when its path ahead is newly fraught.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve entered 2023 focused on a central goal: wrestling down the rapid inflation that has plagued American consumers since 2021. But over the past two weeks, that job has become a lot more complicated.

articles.headline: Crypto Wants Its Shine Back
articles.snippet: After a miserable year, cryptocurrency companies are looking for ways to rebrand products that many consumers no longer trust.
articles.abstract: After a miserable year, cryptocurrency companies are looking for ways to rebrand products that many consumers no longer trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a cryptocurrency conference in Denver this month, a group of singers clad in bright orange onesies took the stage to perform what one industry website later described as an anthem for the crypto faithful, a “blockchain ‘Blowin’ in the Wind.’”
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Falling Lithium Prices Are Making Electric Cars More Affordable
articles.snippet: An unexpected decline in the price of an essential battery material, along with those of other commodities, is good news for buyers. But experts disagree on how long low prices will last.
articles.abstract: An unexpected decline in the price of an essential battery material, along with those of other commodities, is good news for buyers. But experts disagree on how long low prices will last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lithium, the common ingredient in almost all electric-car batteries, has become so precious that it is often called white gold. But something surprising has happened recently: The metal’s price has fallen, helping to make electric vehicles more affordable.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: A Different Kind of Pipeline Project Scrambles Midwest Politics
articles.snippet: Plans that would bury carbon underground rather than release it in the air have stoked debate over climate and property rights, creating unlikely alliances and stirring memories of fierce battles over oil.
articles.abstract: Plans that would bury carbon underground rather than release it in the air have stoked debate over climate and property rights, creating unlikely alliances and stirring memories of fierce battles over oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, S.D. — For more than a decade, the Midwest was the site of bitter clashes over plans for thousand-mile pipelines meant to carry crude oil beneath cornfields and cattle ranches.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Alyssa Schukar

articles.headline: Fate of First Republic Hangs in Balance as Shares Plummet Again
articles.snippet: A $30 billion cash infusion and a frantic effort to sell a stake in the bank have done little to calm investors.
articles.abstract: A $30 billion cash infusion and a frantic effort to sell a stake in the bank have done little to calm investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most imperiled bank on Wall Street, First Republic, slid closer to the precipice on Monday as its shares fell 47 percent, down nearly 90 percent since its close on March 8, the day Silicon Valley Bank’s woes incited a financial panic.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland and Maureen Farrell
